top_ideas.description: Mill developed and refined the utilitarian ethics of Jeremy Bentham, advocating that the moral worth of actions is determined by their contribution to overall happiness. He emphasized higher pleasures (intellectual and moral) over lower pleasures (sensual).
Individuals should be free to act however they wish unless their actions harm others. This principle is foundational to Millâ€™s defense of liberty and limited government intervention.

Mill argued that all opinions, even false ones, must be allowed expression, because they either contain some truth or sharpen the truth by testing it. Suppressing ideas prevents intellectual and social progress.

top_ideas.idea: Individuality as a Component of Well-Being
top_ideas.description: True happiness requires the development of individuality. Society must allow people to flourish according to their own nature rather than enforcing conformity.

Mill distinguished between higher (intellectual and moral) pleasures and lower (physical) pleasures, arguing that the former contribute more meaningfully to human flourishing and should be prioritized.
Democracy can be oppressive if the majority imposes its will on minorities. Mill warned that social conformity and public opinion can be as coercive as laws.
Mill advocated for the full legal and social equality of women, arguing that gender inequality was a major barrier to social progress and contrary to principles of justice and liberty.

Mill supported a system where political power is accountable to the people, but believed it should be balanced with protections against mob rule and should cultivate civic education and participation.
Mill argued that open discourse is essential for truth-seeking and societal advancement, and that even offensive or unpopular opinions must be tolerated and debated.
Mill emphasized the role of education in developing moral character, rational thinking, and self-governance. A free society depends on educated individuals capable of critical thought.
Although a classical economist, Mill supported progressive taxation and wealth redistribution to reduce inequality and enable all individuals to pursue happiness.
